docs.text: Explainable Boosting Machine ¶ Explainable Boosting Machine Explainable Boosting Machine (EBM) is a tree-based, cyclic gradient boosting Generalized Additive Model with automatic interaction detection. EBMs are often as accurate as state-of-the-art blackbox models while remaining completely interpretable. Although EBMs are often slower to train than other modern algorithms, EBMs are extremely compact and fast at prediction time.
docs.title: Explainable Boosting Machine

docs.text: Explainable Boosting Machine Explainable Boosting Machine (EBM) is a tree-based, cyclic gradient boosting Generalized Additive Model with automatic interaction detection. EBMs are often as accurate as state-of-the-art blackbox models while remaining completely interpretable. Although EBMs are often slower to train than other modern algorithms, EBMs are extremely compact and fast at prediction time.

docs.text: Cross Sections ¶ Cross sections can be defined in LS-DYNA in two ways: using node set and element sets using Plane The cross-section can be kept persistent with respect to the model by defining it using node and element sets Output ¶ Forces and Moments outputs are controlled using *DATABASE_SECFORCE Extract Node/Element Sets from Plane ¶ The nodes and elements that are selected by solver are outputted to d3hsp . It can be found under interface definition (Source: dynasupport ) Template to convert d3hsp output to sets ``` *SET_NODE/BEAM/SHELL/SOLID_TITLE $# title Title for set $# sid 10001 ````
docs.title: Cross Sections

docs.text: Cross sections can be defined in LS-DYNA in two ways: using node set and element sets using Plane The cross-section can be kept persistent with respect to the model by defining it using node and element sets
docs.title: Cross Sections

docs.text: Open Science ¶ "Nothing is more powerful than an idea whose time has come" Victor Hugo What is Open Science? ¶ Open Science is an umbrella term for a wide range of (proposed) structural changes in the ways science is done. It ranges from Open Access publishing, publishing manuscripts, open peer review and pre-registration of analyses, to open data, open protocols/methods and open source, as well as methods to make data and code Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable (FAIR). teaserbot-labs/delightful-open-science External Resources ¶
docs.title: Open Science

docs.text: "Nothing is more powerful than an idea whose time has come" Victor Hugo
docs.title: Open Science

docs.text: MultiIndex Dataframe ¶ Provides hierarchical index in a DataFrame Add a new index to existing DataFrame ¶ Using pd.concat() seems to be the easiest way to add a new index (for example, add a new dimension) multiindex_df = pd.concat ([df], keys=['label'], names=['nameOfIndex'], axis=1) Notes: axis=0 add in rows direction and axis=1 adds in the columns direction Combine MultiIndex DataFrame s ¶ DataFrame s of similar dimensions can be combined using newdf = pd.concat([df1,df2], axis=1)
docs.title: MultiIndex Dataframe

docs.text: Testing in Python ¶ Why do automated testing? Ensure code is running as intended, especially making sure that old code is still working when new code is introduced Levels of testing Unit test : evaluate individual modules, as stand alones Integration test : evaluate more than one modules together, making sure they work well together Functional test: end-to-end testing of library features Learning Resources Blog series: How to Write Unit Tests in Python, Part 1: Fizz Buzz - miguelgrinberg.com Testing Jupyter Notebooks ¶ nteract/testbook
docs.title: Testing in Python

docs.text: Why do automated testing? Ensure code is running as intended, especially making sure that old code is still working when new code is introduced Levels of testing Unit test : evaluate individual modules, as stand alones Integration test : evaluate more than one modules together, making sure they work well together Functional test: end-to-end testing of library features Learning Resources Blog series: How to Write Unit Tests in Python, Part 1: Fizz Buzz - miguelgrinberg.com

docs.text: Matplotlib ¶ Getting started ¶ matplotlib/cheatsheets: Official Matplotlib cheat sheets Python Plotting With Matplotlib (Guide) – Real Python matplotlib/AnatomyOfMatplotlib: Anatomy of Matplotlib -- tutorial developed for the SciPy conference rougier/matplotlib-tutorial: Matplotlib tutorial for beginner The Lifecycle of a Plot — Matplotlib 3.3.4 documentation This tutorial aims to show the beginning, middle, and end of a single visualization using Matplotlib. We'll begin with some raw data and end by saving a figure of a customized visualization. Along the way we try to highlight some neat features and best-practices using Matplotlib. Pyplot vs Object Oriented Interface · Matplotblog In-depth ¶ Tutorials — Matplotlib 3.3.4 documentation This page contains more in-depth guides for using Matplotlib. It is broken up into beginner, intermediate, and advanced sections, as well as sections covering specific topics.
docs.title: Matplotlib

docs.text: Reading Papers ¶ jtleek/readingpapers: A guide to reading scientific papers Questions to ask while reading a paper ¶ Ten simple rules for reading a scientific paper What do the author(s) want to know (motivation)? What did they do (approach/methods)? Why was it done that way (context within the field)? What do the results show (figures and data tables)? How did the author(s) interpret the results (interpretation/discussion)? What should be done next?
docs.title: Reading Papers

docs.text: jtleek/readingpapers: A guide to reading scientific papers
docs.title: Reading Papers

docs.text: Ten simple rules for reading a scientific paper What do the author(s) want to know (motivation)? What did they do (approach/methods)? Why was it done that way (context within the field)? What do the results show (figures and data tables)? How did the author(s) interpret the results (interpretation/discussion)? What should be done next?
docs.title: Questions to ask while reading a paper

docs.text: Peer-reviewing papers ¶ jtleek/reviews: Writing reviews of academic papers jtleek/reviews: Writing reviews of academic papers Three tasks you are responsible for as a peer reviewer: Evaluating the quality and accuracy of the methods, data, and results. Determining whether the methods, data and results justify the claims. Determining how important the claims are and whether they belong in the journal the paper was submitted to.
docs.title: Peer-reviewing papers

docs.text: jtleek/reviews: Writing reviews of academic papers jtleek/reviews: Writing reviews of academic papers Three tasks you are responsible for as a peer reviewer: Evaluating the quality and accuracy of the methods, data, and results. Determining whether the methods, data and results justify the claims. Determining how important the claims are and whether they belong in the journal the paper was submitted to.
docs.title: Peer-reviewing papers

docs.text: Productivity ¶ Some tips Daily highlight: Write down 1 thing that needs to get down that day, focus on it. (Book: Make time) Use a to-do list Time blocking: blocks on calendar (Cal Newport) Parkinson's law: work expands to fill the time we allocate to it. Protected time: keep recurring blocks of time for focused work. For example, no Zoom calls in the mornings Delegation Automated scheduling (Calendly) 1 https://twitter.com/AliAbdaal/status/1384088804206596097 ↩
docs.title: Productivity

For example, no Zoom calls in the mornings Delegation Automated scheduling (Calendly) 1 https://twitter.com/AliAbdaal/status/1384088804206596097 ↩

docs.text: VSCode ¶ Tips,Tricks, and Shortcuts ¶ Compare files ¶ Select the files to compare on the Explorer pane (on the left), right click and chose Compare Selected ( stackoverflow ) Cursor ¶ Vertical select : Alt + Shift Multiple cursors Alt + click Vertically add more cursors Ctrl + Alt + Up/Down Add cursor at the next occurrence of the word : Ctrl+D Add cursor at every occurrence of the word : Ctrl+Shift+L File Explorer ¶ Open in Explorer : Alt + Shft + R Git ¶ Move to the next/previous diff : Alt + F5 / Alt + Shift + F5 Search ¶ in whole workspace: Ctrl + Shft + F in a sub-folder within whole workspace: Alt + Shft + F Snippets ¶ To include, a snippet within a snippet (nested snippet) Add the prefix of nested snippet as label Use Ctrl + Space at the tab stop Caveat: This breaks the snippet flow. If using this, have the nested snippet as the last tab stop Hat tip : Stackoverflow
docs.title: VSCode

docs.text: Git ¶ tool for version control Lingo ¶ Commit: a new revision/edit/unit of change Branch : tag pointing to an independent line of commits, branched from the default line The default branch used to called master . It is more common to call it main now Visualization for Git ¶ A better way than file-and-folder view to get an overview of a repo? Fingerprint using githubocto/repo-visualizer Web app Repo Advanced ¶ git worktree : open multiple branches/commits as different folders

docs.text: git worktree : open multiple branches/commits as different folders
docs.title: Advanced

docs.text: git worktree ¶ open multiple Git branches/commits in different folders. Helps to eliminate needless commits and stash I find this very helpful when I need to open multiple versions/branches at the same time. This is especially useful to open different branches of LS-DYNA model files, as each one would have a different output files. Examples ¶ git worktree add dir1 branch1 This starts a new folder dir1 and checks out branch1 git worktree add ../foldername branch-name git worktree add ../foldername commit-hash Commands ¶ git worktree add <path> [<commit-ish/branch>] git worktree list [<options>] git worktree lock [<options>] <path> git worktree move <worktree> <new-path> git worktree prune [<options>] git worktree remove [<options>] <worktree> git worktree unlock <path> Resources ¶ Demo by ThePrimeagen Simple git worktree tutorial
docs.title: git worktree

docs.text: open multiple Git branches/commits in different folders. Helps to eliminate needless commits and stash I find this very helpful when I need to open multiple versions/branches at the same time. This is especially useful to open different branches of LS-DYNA model files, as each one would have a different output files.

docs.text: git worktree add dir1 branch1 This starts a new folder dir1 and checks out branch1 git worktree add ../foldername branch-name git worktree add ../foldername commit-hash

docs.text: git branch ¶ Change default branch name to main ¶ Rename in local repo: git branch -m master main Push to remote repo: git push -u origin main Go to remote hosting platform (github/gitlab) and change the default branch to main The master branch is usually protected. Remove this so that it can be deleted Either delete master branch online or use git push origin --delete master
docs.title: `git branch`

docs.text: Rename in local repo: git branch -m master main Push to remote repo: git push -u origin main Go to remote hosting platform (github/gitlab) and change the default branch to main The master branch is usually protected. Remove this so that it can be deleted Either delete master branch online or use git push origin --delete master
docs.title: Change default branch name to main

docs.text: git stash ¶ Temporarily stash away changes that you don't want to commit yet Basics ¶ Temporarily put away: git stash Get them back: git stash pop
docs.title: `git stash`
